sentences: Qigang Chen ([tʂʰə̌n t͡ɕǐkɑ́ŋ]; Chinese: 陈其钢; pinyin: Chén Qígāng; born 8 August 1951) is a Chinese-French composer who has lived in France since 1984 and obtained French citizenship in 1992.
Coming from an intellectual family, Qigang Chen was born in Shanghai and began his musical studies as a child.
In his early teens, he was confronted with the Cultural Revolution and would spend three years locked up in a barracks, undergoing an "ideological reeducation".
In 1977, Chen was one of 26 candidates out of 2,000 to be accepted into the composition class at the Beijing Central Conservatory.
After five years of studies with Luo Zhongrong, in 1983 he stood for the national competition where he came first.
In 2001, his orchestral work Wu Xing was selected from over 1000 entries as one of the five finalists of the Masterprize Award, hosted by the BBC.
In 2003, EMI/Virgin Classics released an album devoted to his music, including the highly acclaimed work Iris devoilée.
In 2005, he was awarded the Grand Prix de la Musique Symphonique by SACEM in recognition of his career achievement.
He worked as Music Director of the Opening Ceremony of the 2008 Olympic Games in Beijing.
Most recently, in 2013, he was decorated with Chevalier de l'Ordre des arts et des lettres by the French government.
San Xiao (1995) for bamboo flute, san xian, zheng, and pipa
Voyage d'un rêve (new version from 2017) for flute, harp, percussion, and string trio
Feu d'ombres (1990-1991) for soprano saxophone and small wind ensemble
La Nuit profonde (2001) for jinghu/jing erhu and orchestra
Un Temps disparu (2002) for erhu and orchestra
Er Huang (2009) for piano and orchestra
Joie eternelle (2013) for trumpet in C and orchestra
Poème lyrique II (1990) for baritone and instrumental ensemble
Jiang Tcheng Tse (2017) for solo voice, chorus, and orchestra
Iris dévoilée (Iris Unveiled, 2001) for large orchestra, three female voices, pipa, erhu and banhu, and zheng
Luan Tan (2010–2015) for orchestra
Raise the Red Lantern (Épouses et concubines) (2000)
Gérard Billaudot (Paris, from 1985 to 2007)
